data.title: Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer-Lytton PC (1803-1873)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for Edward Bulwer-Lytton PC born 1803 London, Middlesex, England died 1873 Torquay, Devon, England including ancestors + descendants + 3 photos + 2 genealogist comments + questions + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 25 Apr 2024 | Created 5 Jun 2021

This page has been accessed 480 times.

English writer and politician, Secretary of State for the Colonies

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Bio for rewrite

1.2 Notable Works

2 Sources

Biography

Edward Bulwer-Lytton PC is Notable.

Edward, son of William Earl Bulwer Lytton & Elizabeth, was born on 25 May 1803 and baptised on 15 March 1810 in Marylebone, London, England.[1]

Edward married Anna Rosina Wheeler on 29 August 1827 in Westminster, London, England.[2]

Edward's death (age 67) was registered in the Jan-Feb-Mar quarter of 1873 in the Newton Abbot district.[3]

Bio for rewrite

Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer-Lytton, 1st Baron Lytton, PC (25 May 1803 – 18 January 1873) was an English novelist, poet, playwright and politician. He served as a Whig MP from 1831 to 1841 and a Conservative MP from 1851 to 1866. He was Secretary of State for the Colonies from June 1858 to June 1859, during which time he selected Richard Clement Moody to be the founder of British Columbia. Bulwer-Lytton was offered the Crown of Greece in 1862, after the abdication of King Otto, but declined it. He became Baron Lytton of Knebworth in the British peerage in 1862. On 20 February 1844, in accordance with his mother's will, he changed his surname from 'Bulwer' to 'Bulwer-Lytton' and assumed the arms of Lytton by royal licence. His widowed mother had done the same in 1811. His brothers remained plain "Bulwer". [4]

Notable Works

Among his notable works are various novels:

The Last Days of Pompei, 1834, inspired by a painting he saw in Milan

Rienzi, the last of the Roman Tribunes, 1835. Composer Richard Wagner based his opera Rienzi, der Letzte der Tribunen upon this novel. The opera premiered in 1843 and was almost a bigger success than the novel itself.

Harold, the last of the Saxons, 1848, another work that inspired an opera. This time Guiseppe Verdi was inspired by the work and based his opera Aroldo on the novel.

Vril, the Power of the Coming Race, 1871, an early science fiction novel about a subterranean race waiting to reclaim the surface of the earth
